core_meaning.normalized_summary: Ritual readiness, not performance. You are being seen. True authority is built by visible sincerity and inner dignity. The hexagram teaches contemplative self-examination, because others will follow what you are, not what you claim. Leadership begins with looking at yourself clearly.

translations.text: 1. The first line, divided, shows the looking of a ladnot blamable in men of inferior rank, but matter for regret in superior men.
初六：童觀，小人無咎，君子吝。

lines.normalized_meaning: Naive, shallow looking. For ordinary people, limited vision is fine. For someone in a higher role, it's embarrassing to see only like a child.

translations.text: 2. The second line, divided, shows one peeping out from a door. It would be advantageous if it were (merely) the firm correctness of a female.

lines.normalized_meaning: Cautious, partial view from behind the door. That kind of reserved watching is acceptable in a protected/yin position — but it's not enough for open public responsibility.

translations.text: 3. The third line, divided, shows one looking at (the course of) his own life, to advance or recede (accordingly).

lines.normalized_meaning: Turn the gaze inward. Study your own path and choose whether to go forward or pull back. Observation guides timing.

translations.text: 4. The fourth line, divided, shows one contem plating the glory of the kingdom. It will be ad vantageous for him, being such as he is, (to seek) to be a guest of the king.
六四：觀國之光，利用賓于王。

lines.normalized_meaning: You witness the radiance of rightful rule — the larger order. It's favorable now to approach and serve that center with respect.

translations.text: 5. The fifth line, undivided, shows its subject contemplating his own life(-course), A superior man, he will (thus) fall into no error.

lines.normalized_meaning: The one in power reflects on their own conduct. This self-audit keeps the leader from going off track.
